questiontext.text:
Exercise

Find the Jacobian for the transformation \(\,x=u^2+vw\), \(\,y=2v+u^2 w\), \(\,z=uvw\)

\( J(u,v,w) = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to find the Jacobian \(J(u,v,w)\) for the transformation \(\,x=u^2+vw\), \(\,y=2v+u^2 w\), \(\,z=uvw.\)

Evaluating the partial derivatives,

\( \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial u}= 2u, \qquad \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial v}= w, \qquad\dfrac{\partial x}{\partial w}= v\)

\( \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial u}= 2wu, \qquad \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial v}= 2, \qquad\dfrac{\partial y}{\partial w}= u^2\)

\( \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial u}= vw, \qquad \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial v}= uw, \qquad \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial w}= uv\)

and so the Jacobian is: \[\left| \begin{array}{cc} \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial u} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial v} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial z} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial u} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial v} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial w} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial u} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial v} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial w} \end{array} \right| = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} 2u & w & v \\ \\ 2wu & 2 & u^2 \\ \\ vw & uw & uv \end{array}\right| = 2u \left| \begin{array}{ccc} 2 & u^2 \\ uw & uv \end{array}\right| -w \left| \begin{array}{ccc} 2wu & u^2 \\ vw & uv \end{array}\right| +v \left| \begin{array}{ccc} 2wu & 2 \\ vw & uw \end{array}\right| \]

Evaluating the determinants and simplifying, we get

\[\begin{align} J(u,v,w) &= 2u(2uv - u^3w) - w(2wu^2v - u^2vw) + v(2w^2u^2 - 2vw) \\ &= {@ta1@}. \end{align}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
